facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated September 15, 1952, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 2256 of 1947 and 2545 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated September 15, 1952, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 2256 of 1947and 2545 of 1948, arising.

facts.text: Second Appeals arose out of judgment and decree dated September 19, 1946, of the Court of Subordinate Judge of Kozhikode in Appeal Suit Nos. 336 and 180 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: out of the judgment and decree dated September 19, 1946, of the Court of Subordinate Judge of Kozhikode in Appeal Suit Nos. 336 and 180 of 1946, against the judgment

facts.text: Subordinate Judge appeals against judgments dated October 9, 1945 and June 29, 1946 of District Munsif, Chowghat in S. Nos. 131 and 158 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: and decree dated October 9, 1945, and June 29, 1946, respectively of the Court of Districts Munsif, Chowghat, in S. Nos. 131 and 158 of 1945.

facts.text: Will executed on February 10, 1906 by Kunhan Kaimal, Kesavan Kaimal, and Theyi Amma.

anchor.surface_text: Will executed on 28th Makaram 1081 M. E., companyresponding to 10th February, 1906, jointly by Kunhan Kaimal, son of Karayamvattath Katbayakkal Kunhu Kutti Amma, Kesavan Kaimal, son of Theyi Amma and Theyi Amma, daughter of Nani Amma of Etathiruthi amsom and Etamuttan desom in Ponnani Taluk.

facts.text: Theyi Amma died first, exact date not appearing and not material.

anchor.surface_text: of the three testators, Theyi Amma died first-the exact date of her death does number appear and is number very material-and Kunhan Kaimal died thereafter sometime in 1930.

facts.text: Kunhan Kaimal died sometime in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: and Kunhan Kaimal died thereafter sometime in 1930. It is the case of Kesavan Kaimal that in the events which had happened, he had become entitled by survivorship to all the properties disposed of by the will,

facts.text: Kesavan Kaimal conveyed seven items of properties on October 14, 1938 to Sankarankutti Kaimal, of which three belonged to Kunhan Kaimal.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of Kesavan Kaimal that in the events which had happened, he had become entitled by survivorship to all the properties disposed of by the will, including those of Kunhan Kaimal, and on this footing he companyveyed on October 14,1938, seven items of properties, of which three belonged to Kunhan Kaimal, to one Sankarankutti Kaimal

facts.text: Kesavan Kaimal conveyed another three items of properties belonging to Kunhan Kaimal on October 16, 1944 to Kalyani and Vijayan.

anchor.surface_text: and on October 16, 1944, another three items of properties which belonged to Kunhan Kaimal, to Kalyani and Vijayan. These transfers led to the two litigations which have culminated in the present appeals.

facts.text: Legatees under the 1906 will instituted O.S. No. 131 of 1945 in District Munsif, Chowghat for recovery of possession of three items belonged to Kunhan Kaimal after redeeming mortgage for Rs. 100 created on February 3, 1901.

anchor.surface_text: The legatees under the will dated February 10, 1906, instituted O. S. No. 131 of 1945 in the Court of the District Munsif, Chowghat, then in the Province of Madras, for recovery of possession of three items of properties which had belonged to Kunhan Kaimal after redeeming a mortgage for Rs. 100 created over those properties on February 3, 1901.

facts.text: Mortgage for Rs. 100 created over properties on February 3, 1901.

anchor.surface_text: for recovery of possession of three items of properties which had belonged to Kunhan Kaimal after redeeming a mortgage for Rs. 100 created over those properties on February 3, 1901.

facts.text: In O.S. 131/1945, Defendants 1 to 3 were mortgagees, Defendant 6 was Kesavan Kaimal, Defendants 4 and 5 claiming under transfer by D6 dated October 16, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claimed that on the death of Kunhan Kaimal in 1930 they had become entitled to those properties as legatees under the will. Defendants 1 to 3 represented the mortgagees. Defendant 6 was Kesavan Kaimal, and defendants 4 and 5 were brought on record as persons claiming to be entitled to the suit properties under a deed of transfer by defendant 6, dated October 16, 1944.

facts.text: Defendants 4 to 6 contested O.S. 131/1945 claiming properties of Kunhan Kaimal survived to Kesavan Kaimal on death in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 4 to 6 companytested the suit, and pleaded that on a proper companystruction of the will, the properties of Kunhan Kaimal survived to Kesavan Kaimal on the death of the former in 1930, and that the plaintiffs got numbertitle to them.

facts.text: District Munsif decreed O.S. 131/1945 overruling defendants' contention.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was overruled by the District Munsif, and the suit was decreed. There were two appeals against this decree, A. S. No. 179 of 1946 and A. S. No. 180 of 1946 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Calicut,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed appeals A.S. No. 179 and 180 of 1946 agreeing with District Munsif.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge agreed with the companystruction put on the will by the District Munsif, and dismissed the appeals. Against that decree, defendant 6 preferred S. A. No. 2256 of 1947 in the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Sankarankutti Kaimal instituted O.S. No. 158 of 1945 based on transfer dated October 14, 1938 for possession of three items.

anchor.surface_text: Basing himself on the deed of transfer dated October 14, 1938, Sankarankutti Kaimal instituted O. S. No. 158 of 1945 in the Court of the District Munsif, Chowghat, for recovery of possession of three items of properties, of which one belonged to Kunhan Kaimal absolutely and the other two to him and others as companyowners.

facts.text: District Munsif dismissed O.S. 158/1945 on June 29, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The District Munsif found all the companytentions in favour of defendants 1 to 3 and dismissed the suit., Against this decree, there was an appeal, A. S. No. 336 of 1946,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Ottapalam dismissed A.S. No. 336 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree, there was an appeal, A. S. No. 336 of 1946, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Ottapalam, and that was dismissed, the Subordinate Judge agreeing with the District Munsif on all the issues.

facts.text: Madras High Court before Raghava Rao J. allowed both second appeals on September 15, 1952, holding will created joint ownership vesting to Kesavan Kaimal by survivorship.

anchor.surface_text: Both the second appeals came up for hearing before Raghava Rao J. who held that on its true companystruction the will operated to vest, in the three testators all the properties companyered by it in joint ownership, that, in companysequence, on the death successively of Theyi Amma and Kunhan Kaimal, their interest survived to Kesavan Kaimal, and that the transfers made by him on October 14, 1938, and October 16, 1944, were valid.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the will dated February 10, 1906 did not make the three testators joint owners; it is a testamentary disposition operating on death of each.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the question fully argued, we have companye to the companyclusion that that is number the effect of the will, and that the judgment of the High Court companytra cannot be supported.

facts.text: Each testator possessed self-acquired properties and some jointly acquired as tenants-in-common.

anchor.surface_text: There were three executants of the will. Each of them possessed properties, which were his or her self- acquisitions. They- also owned some properties which they had jointly acquired, but their title to such properties was as tenants-in-common and number as joint tenants.

facts.text: Partition deed dated May 16, 1915 to which Kesavan Kaimal was a party.

anchor.surface_text: As against this, the appellant referred us to a partition deed dated May 16, 1915, and a mortgage deed dated March 4, 1926, to both of which Kesavan Kaimal was a party,

facts.text: Mortgage deed dated March 4, 1926 to which Kesavan Kaimal was a party.

anchor.surface_text: and a mortgage deed dated March 4, 1926, to both of which Kesavan Kaimal was a party, in which be and other members of the family had understood the will in question as meaning that the testators held the properties companyered by the will in separate and exclusive ownership.
Against this judgment, the present appeals have been brought on a certificate granted by this court under Art. 136.

holdings.text: The will dated February 10, 1906 did not operate to vest all properties covered by it in the three testators as joint owners with survivorship to Kesavan Kaimal.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the question fully argued, we have come to the conclusion that that is not the effect of the will, and that the judgment of the High Court contra cannot be supported.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction shows it is a testamentary disposition operating on each testator's death, not inter vivos joint tenancy; supported by lack of divesting words, stamp requirement, future properties, alienation clause, and tenants-in-common status.

holdings.text: Kesavan Kaimal did not become entitled under the will to the properties of Kunhan Kaimal by survivorship.

anchor.surface_text: The point for determination in these two appeals is whether one Kesavan Kaimal who was one of three executants of a will dated February 10, 1906, became entitled under that will to the properties, which

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will is joint testamentary disposition; each testator's properties pass to legatees on death, not to surviving testator.

holdings.text: The will cannot be construed as an inter vivos transfer of individual properties to the testators jointly as joint tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondents which has found favour with the High Court is that the will must be construed as a transfer by the several testators of all their individual properties to themselves

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Will' means disposition on death; would require stamp as present transfer but is unstamped; no divesting words.

holdings.text: There are no words in the will divesting the testators of individual ownership and vesting it jointly.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the recitals in the will, there are no words by which the executants thereof divest themselves of their individual ownership and vest it in themselves jointly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual analysis of recitals shows retention of individual control until death.

holdings.text: Properties to be acquired in future cannot be subject of present inter vivos disposition.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to imagine how properties which were to be acquired in future could form the subject-matter of a disposition in praesenti.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical impossibility for future acquisitions in present transfer.

holdings.text: Clause 3 allowing testators to alienate properties jointly or severally is inconsistent with joint tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: the terms of clause 3, which provides that the testators could alienate the properties jointly or severally. If the properties were intended to be impressed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint tenancy prohibits unilateral alienation; clause permits it, indicating separate ownership.

holdings.text: The will refers to properties jointly acquired as tenants-in-common, not joint properties with survivorship.

anchor.surface_text: But this reasoning is based on a misconception of the recitals in the will. The will does not refer to any joint properties of the testators but to properties jointly acquired by them-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between joint acquisition (tenants-in-common) and joint tenancy; shares devolve separately.

holdings.text: Evidence of subsequent conduct is inadmissible to interpret clear and unambiguous will language.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule excludes conduct evidence where document unambiguous.

holdings.text: The will is a joint will operating as testamentary disposition of each testator's properties on their death, equivalent to three wills in one.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Halsbury, Jarman, Duddell: joint will disposes separate properties on each death.

holdings.text: The will is not a mutual will.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutual wills require reciprocal benefits between testators as legatees; here legatees are distinct.

holdings.text: On the death of Kunhan Kaimal, his properties vested in the legatees under the will, not Kesavan Kaimal or his transferees.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of joint will construction to facts.

precedents.citation: Duddell in re. Roundway V. Roundway 1 1932 1 Ch. 585, 592

anchor.surface_text: The following observations of Farewell J. in Duddell in re. Roundway V. Roundway  1  are apposite in my judgment it is plain on the authorities that there may be a joint will in the sense that if two people make a bargain to make a joint will, effect may be given to that document. On the death of the first of those two persons the will is admitted to probate as a disposition of the property that be possesses. On the death of the second person, assuming that numberfresh will has been made, the will is admitted to probate as the disposition of the second persons property

precedents.case_name: In re Duddell; Roundway v Roundway
precedents.cited_proposition: A joint will by two or more testators operates on the death of each as the will of that testator disposing of his own property, and is in effect separate wills
precedents.cited_holding: in my judgment it is plain on the authorities that there may be a joint will in the sense that if two people make a bargain to make a joint will, effect may be given to that document. On the death of the first of those two persons the will is admitted to probate as a disposition of the property that be possesses. On the death of the second person, assuming that numberfresh will has been made, the will is admitted to probate as the disposition of the second persons property

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the question fully argued, we have come to the conclusion that that is not the effect of the will, and that the judgment of the High Court contra cannot be supported.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment not supported and reversed; will held to be testamentary disposition vesting properties in legatees on death of each testator; Kesavan Kaimal not entitled by survivorship; transfers by Kesavan Kaimal invalid
